;;H;;ARVEY WEINSTEIN;，前好莱坞大亨和;#MeToo运动;的头号公敌，再次获得自由——至少就纽约最高法院而言是这样。 4 月 25 日，曼哈顿上诉法院裁定，韦恩斯坦在 2020 年因性犯罪重罪指控被定罪，并被判处 23 年监禁，因此没有受到公平审判。他可能面临重审，并因强奸罪被判处 16 年监禁，在加州服刑，因此仍将继续服刑。但这一决定的象征意义是重大的，也是 #MeToo 迄今为止最大的挫折。

;

;尽管这一裁决令公众感到震惊公众，但对法律界的许多人来说，事实并非如此。 2023 年，YouGov 的一项民意调查发现，83% 的美国人认为韦恩斯坦犯有强奸和性侵犯等指控，只有 5% 的人认为他无罪，“无论判决如何”。不过，尽管舆论法庭对韦恩斯坦的罪名毫无疑问——他被 100 多名女性指控犯有从骚扰到强奸等各种行为——但他在纽约的刑事定罪始终站不住脚。正如《经济学人》当时所写，法官允许三名未参与指控的证人就之前的“不良行为”作证的决定颇具争议;

;
;
;
;
;

;七名上诉法院法官中的四名表示同意，并在长达 77 页的裁决中裁定初审法院“错误地接受了未受到指控的、涉嫌先前性行为的证词”。当法官裁定韦恩斯坦先生可以就这些以及其他以“高度偏见的眼光”描绘他的指控进行盘问时，这些错误变得更加复杂。法官们强调，根据纽约的制度，被告有权仅因所指控的罪行而被追究责任。 “即使是最不受欢迎的刑事被告也应该受到公平审判，”刑事辩护律师丹尼尔·霍赫海塞尔 (Daniel Hochheiser) 说。他说，额外的证人“除了毒害陪审团对韦恩斯坦的指控之外，没有其他目的”。

;

;检方的策略是可以理解，如果有风险的话。家庭暴力和性犯罪案件的检察官经常主张允许从正在审理的案件之外传唤原告。在韦恩斯坦案的审判中，他们认为“选角沙发”文化构成了一种模式，在这种文化中，女性通过性行为来换取角色，并且需要额外的证人来为陪审团确立这种模式。 《可信：为什么我们怀疑指控者并保护施暴者》一书的作者黛博拉·图尔克海默表示，该案暴露了法律制度要求任何与指控无关的证据不得进入法庭的要求与社会对证据的要求之间的根本紧张关系。 “数十名原告”在受害者被相信之前挺身而出。她说，“引力”是为了召唤更多证人。

;;

;#WhereNow？

;

;在他们的裁决中纽约法官得出的结论是：“纠正这些严重错误的方法是重新审判。”曼哈顿地区检察官办公室证实将寻求一名这样的人。与此同时，现在所有的目光都转向韦恩斯坦先生在洛杉矶的上诉，他将于 5 月 20 日提出上诉。 （韦恩斯坦先生正在纽约州北部服刑，他将被带到洛杉矶开始在那里服刑。）他的一位律师辩称，因为韦恩斯坦先生在这里也“遭受了未受指控的猛烈攻击”。指控，这一定罪也应同样被推翻。这似乎不太可能。与纽约相反，加利福尼亚州（与许多其他州甚至联邦法院一样）对于允许“其他行为”证人在性侵犯案件中出庭作证更为宽松。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;人们很容易将韦恩斯坦先生的定罪推翻视为对#MeToo运动的强烈抵制。在一份尖锐的异议中，上诉法官之一玛德琳·辛加斯(Madeline Singas)写道：“连续性地利用自己对女性的权力——尤其是社会上最弱势的群体——的男性将从今天的判决中获益。”然而，针对韦恩斯坦先生的各种指控并非毫无意义。一些州司法系统的改进，例如废除阻止受害者发声的保密协议以及延长诉讼时效，可以直接归因于#MeToo/韦恩斯坦的遗产。前联邦检察官伊丽莎白·格迪斯 (Elizabeth Geddes) 于 2021-22 年间在纽约对歌手 R 凯利 (R Kelly) 敲诈勒索和性犯罪定罪。她表示，韦恩斯坦最初的判决帮助克服的一个挑战是“如何说服潜在受害者，这次法律执法部门会严肃对待你”。

;

;如果进行重审，纽约检察官将有很大机会对先生定罪。又是韦恩斯坦。对他进行重审的决定的核心是能否说服原告再次出庭作证。这是一场人们已经说过愿意再次战斗的战斗。;■;

;;I;;N 2017 EMMANUEL MACRON; took to the stage under the domed amphitheatre of the Sorbonne in Paris to call for a more “sovereign”, autonomous Europe. Filled with as many abstract nouns as policy ideas, the speech came to mark the French president's ambition for the European Union to toughen up, and stand on its own two feet.七年后的 4 月 25 日，马克龙先生回到大学，传达了一条更为严肃的信息：“我们的欧洲终有一死； it can die”.

;

;The underlying thread in Mr Macron's long speech was one of Europe's fragility in a darker world.他有时会提到欧洲计划，狭义上是指欧盟的 27 个成员国。几十年来，它的居民逐渐认为<小>;欧盟;是景观的一个固定特征；马克龙强调，这种构想可能会因民族主义的复苏而被摧毁。但他也将欧洲视为一个更广泛的共享自由民主空间，“从里斯本到敖德萨”，这是对饱受战争摧残的乌克兰的肯定。

;
;As ever, Mr Macron supplied no shortage of ideas in order to face up to such threats. His included the familiar, such as an offer to discuss the European dimension to France's nuclear deterrent.其他一些新鲜事，包括呼吁将欧盟预算增加一倍，这将激怒他的邻国，尤其是德国，他呼吁在国防采购中“优先考虑欧洲”——尽管德国总理奥拉夫·肖尔茨(Olaf Scholz)发布了关于整个演讲异常热情的信息。 Mr Macron also wants big hikes in public spending to keep Europe in the tech race when it comes to artificial intelligence, quantum computing, space, biotech and innovative energy.

;

;In a practical sense Mr Macron used the speech to set out an agenda for Europe's institutions, which will be renewed for five years after elections to the European Parliament in June this year and the appointment of a new European Commission. Indeed, the president's detractors denounced the speech as flagrant electioneering, at a time when his centrist political party, Renaissance, is in trouble. It is trailing Marine Le Pen's hard-right National Rally by about 13 percentage points.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Yet, in the gravity of Mr Macron's words and the depth of his furrowed brow, there was a sense that this was about his legacy, and about political mortality too.欧洲是他政治计划的核心，自 2017 年首次竞选以来，他一直在这样做。在这个问题上，他与疫情和俄罗斯的侵略一起，可以说已经留下了印记，帮助实现这一目标。非洲大陆采取更加大胆的行动。这位 46 岁的领导人无法在 2027 年的下一届总统选举中连续第三届连任。真正令人担忧的问题是谁将追随他。马克龙先生说欧洲可能会灭亡。勒庞担任总统可能会成为刽子手。 ;■;

;;I;;T IS DIFFICULT; to wrap your mind around California.金州比许多国家面积更大、人口更多，经济也与之相匹配。这里有高耸的山脉、无情的沙漠和看似无尽的海岸线。得益于好莱坞和硅谷，美国没有一个州对现代文化和技术产生了如此大的影响。 And, like America, California is not just a place but an idea: a golden land of opportunity at the edge of the continent where generations of miners, migrants, farmers, actors and computer geeks have sought success. It is perhaps because of this idealistic vision that California's troubles, and those of its superstar cities, Los Angeles and San Francisco, can seem especially acute. It is also America's most liberal state, earning it the admiration of progressives and the ire of conservatives, for whom California has become shorthand for everything wrong in America.没有一本书能够真正阐释加州的含义。 But these five, taken together, make for a good start.

;;

;;California: A History. ;By Kevin Starr. ;Modern Library; 416 pages; $20;

;

;For a broad overview of California's story start with Kevin Starr's one-volume history of the state.这位历史学家兼前国家图书馆馆长不知何故设法涵盖了从 16 世纪西班牙人沿着太平洋海岸进行的探索性航行到阿诺德·施瓦辛格 2003 年赢得州长选举的所有内容。当然，这本书不会回答读者可能提出的有关国家的所有问题， but it is an extremely useful jumping-off point, and an introduction to California's many eras: Indigenous, Spanish, Mexican and, finally, American.

;

;;Holy Land : A Suburban Memoir. ;By DJ Waldie. ;WW Norton; 208 pages; $14.95;

;

;It is hard to understand Los Angeles, and California more broadly, without considering its suburbs.战后的建设热潮改变了曾经覆盖洛杉矶县的农田和果园。 Lakewood was the west coast's answer to New York's Levittown: row after row of tract houses that became suburbs that became sprawl. DJ Waldie grew up in one such house. His book is a reflection on suburban life and the appearance of order and conformity. “I live where a majority of Americans live,” the book begins. It is “one of the places where suburban stories were first mass-produced.”

;

;;Slouching Towards Bethlehem. ;By Joan Didion. ;Farrar, Straus and Giroux; 256 pages; $18;

;

;Several other books by Joan Didion could easily have made this list. She was a daughter of Sacramento, and wrote often about her home state. But it was her unflinching portrait of San Francisco's Haight-Ashbury neighbourhood in 1967, when “the centre was not holding”, that catapulted Didion into the pantheon of California writers. “San Francisco was where the social haemorrhaging was showing up,” she wrote, when runaways, protesters and rock 'n rollers disenchanted with America, with their lives, colonised Golden Gate Park. Other essays in this collection explore the rising rivers of the Sacramento Valley, the middle-class striving of the Inland Empire (where ;LA;'s exurbs meet the desert) and the vagaries of Los Angeles. Didion tried to puzzle out in prose what California meant, and probably came closer than anyone. “California is a place”, she wrote, “in which the mind is troubled by some buried but ineradicable suspicion that things had better work here, because here, beneath that immense bleached sky, is where we run out of continent.”

;

;;The Grapes of Wrath;. By John Steinbeck. ;Penguin; 464 pages; $21;

;

;More than half of John Steinbeck's classic book takes place either in Oklahoma or on dusty roads headed west. But California is ever present: first as an idea, even before the Joad family crosses the desert and arrives in Bakersfield's squalid migrant camps. And then as a disappointing reality, when families can't find work in the fields and the fruit rots on the trees because small-time farmers can't pay for labour. Steinbeck manages to capture the devastation that the Dust Bowl wrought on the Great Plains and the promise, and eventual disappointment, that California held for the poor farmers streaming west out of America's parched middle in the 1930s.

;

;John Muir's account of his “rambles” through the Sierra Nevada during the summer of 1869 is equal parts diary, poem and field guide. The famed naturalist is ostensibly watching over a flock of sheep, and yet he leaves them at any chance he gets to explore the lakes, peaks and valleys of one of North America's great mountain ranges. Muir can be tedious when he is rhapsodising about the magnificence of the Yosemite Valley in abstract, almost religious, terms. But he is engaging and funny when he is recounting his adventures, and teaching readers about California's rich natural environment in the meantime. A grasshopper inspires as much reverence as grizzly bears or giant sequoias. Readers will also see something of California's long tradition of environmentalism in Muir's writings. He has only scorn for tourists—but has the presence of mind to realise he is not so different from them.

;;T;;HERE HAS; been no shortage of #GirlPower musicals on Broadway and the West End in recent years. Women make up some 65% of theatre audiences in both America and Britain, so the market for power ballads about female empowerment is robust. Most of these productions, including “& Juliet” (a reimagining of ;William Shakespeare;'s tragic play, with pop songs) and “Six” (about Henry VIII's wives), are playful and poppy. Some, such as “Sylvia”, about the socialist scion of the ;Pankhurst clan;, aim to be provocative. “Suffs”, a new Broadway show about the struggle for women's suffrage in America, falls in the more ambitious camp. It is inspiring, often funny, and very good.

;

;Like ;“Hamilton”,; “Suffs” is a history lesson that feels not just relevant but pressing. Set in the years before the 19th amendment to the United States Constitution gave women the right to vote in 1920, it uses orchestra-backed ballads, ragtime ditties and a catchy song called “Great American Bitch” to dramatise the hard and often fractious work of agitating for change. At its centre is the question at the heart of any social movement: push hard or be patient? Storm the barricades or carefully win over hearts and minds?

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;In period costumes of floor-skimming skirts and flower-topped hats, Carrie Chapman Catt (Jenn Colella) leads a ladylike campaign of slow, steady coalition-building. “It won't disrupt your lives, we'll still be loyal wives, so mister won't you please let mother vote,” she croons pleasantly. Then there's Alice Paul (Shaina Taub, who also wrote and scored the show), a younger, pluckier activist, who insists that the movement needs a big, attention-getting, president-pressuring march, the first of its kind in Washington, ;DC;. “I don't want to have to compromise,” she sings, her voice piercing and urgent. “I don't want to have to beg for crumbs.”

;
;;
;

;“Suffs” captures how these questions were often more fraught for African-American suffragists. Sidelined by a movement that vied for the approval of white southerners, these women reckoned with harder choices: march segregated in the back or not be seen at all? The song “Wait My Turn”, performed by Nikki James as Ida B. Wells, a journalist and activist who had been born into slavery, is at once bitter, potent and rousing.

;

;Ms Taub began writing the book, music and lyrics for “Suffs” in early 2016. At the time, when polls agreed that America was about to elect its first female president, a musical about the achievements of pioneering feminists seemed like a victory lap. Now “Suffs” feels more like a call to arms. “The show keeps getting more timely,” observes Jill Furman, a producer who has been with it from the start.希拉里·克林顿（Hillary Clinton）于2022年首次在百老汇中看到该节目，现在是制片人。 So is ;Malala Yousafzai;, a Pakistani education activist and Nobel Peace laureate. There is already talk about bringing it to audiences beyond the Music Box Theatre in New York with a tour, album and film version.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;That “Suffs” should arrive shortly before an election—and at a time when many American women feel their rights are under siege—feels propitious. (When scanned, QR codes around the theatre take people to a website where they can register to vote.) Yet its message about the value of hope in demoralising times makes it likely that it will live on beyond this year's ;presidential tussle; between two unpopular, aged white men. “The path will be twisted and risky and slow,” the cast sings in the final song, “but keep marching, keep marching.” ;■;
